arm_group.arm_group_label: Distress Tolerance Treatment for Weight Concern (DT-W)
arm_group.description: DT-W is delivered over a 9 week period with 1 1-hr individual session during week 1, 8 weekly 1.5-hr group counseling sessions during weeks 2-9, and 1 20-minute individual telephone session during week 4.  Session content includes distress tolerance intervention for weight concern plus standard behavioral smoking cessation treatment.  Participants also receive 8 weeks of nicotine patch.

HE is delivered over a 9 week period with 1 1-hr individual session during week 1, 8 weekly 1.5-hr group counseling sessions during weeks 2-9, and 1 20-minute individual telephone session during week 4.  Session content includes smoking health education program plus standard behavioral smoking cessation treatment.  Participants also receive 8 weeks of nicotine patch.

brief_summary.textblock:
The long-term goal of this program of research is to develop and disseminate an efficacious
      intervention for weight concern that will significantly increase smoking cessation rates
      among women. The overall objective of this project is to develop this intervention, modify
      it based on piloting and feedback to ensure its feasibility and acceptability, and obtain
      preliminary data supporting its efficacy. These objectives will be accomplished by pursuing
      the following specific aims: 1) develop a group-based distress tolerance treatment for
      weight concern (DT-W) in female smokers and a comparison health education (HE) program and
      pilot both treatments with three groups of 10 (total N = 30) female weight-concerned smokers
      (2 DT-W groups, 1 HE group), 2) conduct a preliminary randomized controlled trial (RCT) (N =
      60) comparing DT-W to a Health Education (HE) comparison intervention, in which both groups
      also receive standard behavioral smoking cessation treatment (ST) including counseling and
      transdermal nicotine patch (TNP), and 3) examine potential mechanisms that may underlie the
      efficacy of DT-W in improving smoking outcomes at 1-, 3-, and 6-month follow-ups.

clinical_study.brief_title: Women Engaging in Quitting Smoking Together (WE QUIT)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  female

          -  18 to 65 years of age

          -  smoke 10 or more cigarettes per day

          -  daily smoker for at least the past year

          -  report motivation to quit smoking in the next month of at least 5 on a 10 point scale

          -  report concern of at least 50 on at least one of two 100 point scales assessing
             weight concern

          -  Body Mass Index < 35

          -  able to travel to Butler Hospital for study appointments

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  past month use of other smoking cessation or weight loss therapies

          -  past month use of other tobacco products

          -  current diagnosis of depression

          -  diagnosis or treatment for non-nicotine substance use disorder during the past 12
             months

          -  lifetime diagnosis or treatment of eating disorder, bipolar disorder, schizophrenia,
             or schizoaffective disorder

          -  current use of psychotropic medication except antidepressants

          -  score above established cut-offs on self-report screening measures of depressive
             symptomology, eating disorder symptomology, alcohol use disorder, or drug use
             disorder

          -  current suicidality or homicidality

          -  medical condition that is a contraindication for the use of transdermal nicotine
             patch

intervention.arm_group_label: Distress Tolerance Treatment for Weight Concern (DT-W)
intervention.intervention_name: Distress Tolerance Treatment for Weight Concern (DT-W)

clinical_study.official_title: Distress Tolerance Treatment for Weight Concern in Smoking Cessation Among Women

primary_outcome.description: We will compare the percentage of participants in each treatment group who report abstinence from smoking for the 7 days prior to each follow-up assessment (1-, 3-, and 6-months post-quit date).

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
